pros: Flexibility in the role, prioritize time with family. Benefits are okay, but costly considering this is an insurance company. If you can get approval, education benefits are good.
cons: Micro-managing more than what is reasonable. Ability to promote and grow, but no support or mentorship within the role once you're there. Unrealistic targets and metrics, no consideration for staff individual strengths if not fitting the metric mould. Uneven pay equity. Below industry standard, unequal across roles for similar experience and backgrounds. Uneven pay distribution. Lack of consistent messages from leaders and leaders are not on the same page. When a decision is made and rolled out to staff, anticipate the message changing multiple times and to be delivered with urgent turnaround. Expectations to be available after hours and on call without compensation. Outdated annual review structure. Next to impossible to be recognized for performing above expectations and next to no compensation for those contributions, other than to be expected to do more in coming years.

pros: 22$/hour is nice. Working remotely.
cons: health insurance options are poor. holidays are few and far and in between. accrual based pto is mediocre. bad middle managers. micromanaging metrics. they expect employees to be working every second even though studies show microbreaks are better and actually improve efficiency. every hour is tracked. every minute is tracked. every second is tracked. bonuses aren't elaborated on and if you got hired too close to the bonus, you won't get it anyway so ignore whatever bonus they're trying to sell you on when considering to work here. middle managers care more about defending dodgey practices and processes than actually making improvements. time is wasted literally talking about how a set number of out going calls didn't happen. they want you making 6 outgoing calls an hour. System problems? too bad. Long calls that need interpreters? too bad. difficult members? too bad. you'll need to document every reason you didn't hit that number. they care more about the numbers they can put on their resume than the turnover dollars they are costing the business. if you can jump when they say jump and be a good lap dog, you'll be just fine.

job_title: Health Concierge/Customer Service in Fresno, CA
pros: Perks are programs you have access to, bonuses if your stats are within their criteria. Health coverage is decent. Pay is decent in itself but realistically not for all the hats and tasks you're required to do. Overtime is occasionally offered. The helpful co-workers were a big plus. Working remotely is great but you will need self-discipline.
cons: No job is perfect, but phone stats required are unrealistic; probably due to ones who felt remote work meant slacking, which ruined it for us who actually sit at our desk the entire time working. 20 wk training was hit or miss w/topics requiring more knowledge. Occasional confusion on procedures between other employees/supervisors. Prepare to do most of the learning/research on your own. Feels like too many programs used to get info needed. Also, make sure you are planning to stay a year before leaving or the bonuses given will be taken back.

pros: Only pro I can think of honestly is some positions you can WFH. that's it
cons: Unnecessary amount of workload.. let's start here... You don't get credit for all they expect you to do for "metrics" . The expectations for the position is ridiculously unrealistic and they continue to add requirements for "state contract"... I just quit and joined another competitor which simplified its workload for it's employees. FOR THE SAME STATE. Lol.. and contract satisfaction. Turnover rate is EXTREMELY high and retention for new employees in case management department is very low. they can't keep anyone. they penalize you for lack of assessment completion which has ZERO to do with you and more often to do with members being unable to reach. Health benefits are bogus to be so "high on the Fortune 500 list" last i checked they stopped bonuses every year now. Applied for 37-40 internal positions and did not get a single one. even with a spotless record regarding work performance and no disciplinary action, leading me to believe they will bottleneck you into being stuck on a team where you can't transfer if they really need employees for that department but they won't tell you. no exit interview upon resignation. just a crappy company. good for couple years experience and bounce.

review_title: Lots of room for advancement....but only if you are young.
pros:
1. Work from home
2. Pay is acceptable
3. PTO amount is also acceptable, but...you have to find your own coverage.
cons:
1. If you are an older employee, expect to get looked over for any promotions or lateral moves. They VERY clearly promote employees in their 20's-40's only. They overlook an impeccable work record, NO sick days taken, 100% on audits, completion of their program for those wanting to advance at the organization, being a team lead, and being a preceptor, in order to promote someone with none of those traits. If you are 50+, you are invisible at Aetna.

2. Change is inevitable, but at Aetna, it is CONSTANT. And I do mean CONSTANT. Don't get used to a process, because I guarantee you, it will change, and quickly. They roll out major changes without trying them first on a small scale to see if they actually work. And they certainly don't involve the employees that the change will involve, in the decision-making/brainstorming process. Do you have a question during the mtgs? Too bad. Email them the question. See where I'm going here? Chaos, frustration and unbelievable stress is the norm. Their answer to all of that? They allow us access to an app to decrease our stress. Nice.

cons: My salary was minimally adjusted each year - now with rampant inflation and the discovery that they're paying much more for new hires, my manager told me that there was nothing he could do to adjust my package, and also that I was being constantly pressured to be back to office despite the dangerous subway situation and growing COVID cases in NYC. And also, very ironically, they offer terrible health insurance benefits as a health insurance - they took hundreds of dollars out of every paycheck, in returns you get a high deductible plan where you at least need to pay 3-4K+ out of pocket before they cover you. What a joke.

Between December and February nobody can take days off even if it's Medical related and if you do they count it against you. It's ver very hard to get help when you need it. They lie to get you in there. If you don't have a job at all then maybe you can deal with Aetna until you get another job, but don't quit a good or decent job like I did to work there, biggest mistake I've ever made and I was warned but didn't listen, I hated working at Aetna, dreaded every day even though it was remotely working from home.

pros: Just that you can work from home
cons:
If you see a job listing with a sign on bonus, just know it comes with an addendum that you have to pay it back if you leave before a year, and if you then you owe it all back. That isn’t the issue. The issue is, you get a letter stating you owe the full amount in two weeks or you will go to collections - and they don’t allow a payment plan. Who has 3k laying around to pay immediately? 
Why would you leave before a year, you may ask? 
Extremely poor training, the micro- micromanaging is the worst I’ve encountered at a job, they call out the employees by name who have low numbers, and they scrutinize any lag between working claims (god forbid you need to stretch your legs). 
Also, for being an insurance company the health insurance they offer should be criminal. Be ready for extremely large deductibles and limited choices.

job_title: Case Management Analyst in Arlington, TX
pros: In the STAR KIDS department there is flexibility/good work life balance. You independently manage your own caseload and the monthly metrics are reasonable.  Since 3/2020 the entire department works at home full time. The department has good supervisors and managers. If you are a lmsw and are hired as a Service Coordinator I/Case Management Analyst I, then you can use the job towards clinical licensure hours to become a lcsw. There is good camaraderie among workers.
cons: There are changes made ALL THE TIME and it is often hard to keep up. The constant changes make it easy to miss items when your charts are audited. When the STAR KIDS program first started in 2016 there were many service coordinators that were hired in with very poor pay. As of 7/2022 there are service coordinators that do not have a masters in social work and make about the same salary as the coordinators (with a masters in social work) that have slaved in the field to complete assessments and service plans. The yearly raises are a joke and the bonuses aren't that great either.  On average, the bonuses will be about 4% of your annual pay. If you consider a job in the STAR KIDS department please negotiate your pay and do not start with a low number! In 2016 there were SCII's that started with at least 50K in pay. Aetna has the ability to pay more but they do not like to. One would assume that the medical benefits would be stellar considering it is Aetna but they are definitely NOT. The medical benefits and the out of pocket cost for things is the worst I have ever had. The paid time off accrual is fair but you can only carry over 40 hours of pto each year. You have to use it or you lose it. When you take a day off you have to find someone to "cover" you in case something arises on your caseload and this isn't always easy. You will also be required to log into the phone queue one day a week for 5 hours and answer incoming calls. This upset almost everyone in the department because instead of hiring staff to address incoming calls they have the service coordinators do it. DO NOT GO TO HR WITH ISSUES BECAUSE YOU WILL BE BLACKBALLED!!!! Lastly, there are definitely certain workers that tell management EVERYTHING. This includes what is shared in private meetings. I would advise anyone new to this job to not over-share or express issues with management to anyone.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Good base pay, decent hours, major holidays off, PTO, incredible insurance, bonuses, discounts, work from home options.
cons:
If you want to work for this company, you better be self reliant and be capable of teaching yourself. The training instructor is self indulgent and spends a vast majority of the time talking about herself, plans etc. I felt like I was in elementary school during my training period. 

I had to go beyond the instructor and learn on my own to be adequately prepared for my calls... And even then, I struggled some. 

The training class was disorganized, full of personal conversations, joking around, loud background noises, people eating loudly into microphones, dogs barking, kids being loud... Leaving very little availability to ask questions or even follow the training material appropriately.

Also, whatever you do .... DO NOT get on the trainers bad side by mentioning these difficulties because she will openly target you in the class or outright ignore you when you have questions. My professionalism out performed hers, which says a lot considering I was only in training and knew nothing about the role. 

I am still actively learning about things I should have picked up during my training period. Unfortunately. However, if you can survive the trainer and the class... You will more than likely do well in the job and love your supervisor! 

The company is great... They need new trainers that can manage the classroom.

review_title: Decent work life balance, but disorganized and dysfunctional work environment
pros: The work life balance was good and I was getting paid a decent amount for my experience level.
cons:
Ever since Aetna was acquired by CVS, the work atmosphere has not been great. For one, there has been 5 re-orgs during the two years that I was there, and one had resulted in me doing a job that I wasn't hired to do three months after joining. I had tried to find ways to enrich my experience there and pursue opportunities that were closer to my interests, but I was always so busy with my current job that I didn't have the time to take on stretch assignments or network across the business. 

There are also limited opportunities for promotions. I was due for one and was given the response "no one has been promoted since COVID," even though I have taken on more work and responsibility since COVID. It also seems like upper management is very disorganized, judging by the constant re-orgs within the company. I've been so burnt out here, by stressing about how all of these org changes will affect me and doing a job that I haven't been fulfilled for that long.

Cheyenne is a great trainer when not mixed in with the wrong crowd of other trainers. There was a few good assistants like Ms. Tammy. review_title: Do NOT work here if you have any health issues
job_title: Health Concierge in New Albany, OH
pros: -My supervisor was the only good thing.
cons:
-Pay is too low for the amount of work you do
-Upper management does not help you with questions/escalations
-Upper management will try to tell you that you aren't sick or you don't have x so they don't have to send you home.
-Upper management will try to control everything you do.
-Someone died in my family and I was allowed 1 day off but upper management had the same thing happen and was off for 2 weeks.
-If you are late to lunch because you are on a call you are messing up your stats.
-If you have to use the restroom at all, you shouldn't use aux/aftercall/ logout you need to wait for your assigned breaks/lunches.
-The late shift sometimes has to stay signed in until almost 6:30 instead of your end time of 6:00pm.
-Almost no overtime is offered.
-Was there for almost 2 years with great stats and QA- never was allowed to move up.
-Needed FMLA- was fired and then sent the documents I had needed.
-They do not care about your mental health even though they say they do.
-Will not give you the time off you need most of the time.
-Any time off needs approved a month in advance.
-If your supervisor likes you they can help get you a day off the day before but most of the time they won't.
-If you are sick at all, you have to tough it out.
-Upper management has a lot of favoritism.

review_title: Work here as a last resort
pros: You get paid, get company equipment, remote work option, some people are good to work with. It may seem okay in the beginning but it gets worse.
cons:
Digital Design at Aetna and CVS health is a toxic wreck, you will regret working there. 
This group has weak leadership throughout Design and "DesignOps". There is EXTREMELY high conflict between departments,  high politics, high egos, many leads, managers and directors who have the "fake it until you make it" mentality that take you in circles or the wrong direction.
Benefits are a joke, they make it hard for you to get them and most the ancillary benefits services are bad quality.  
Overall, this group lacks vision, lacks leadership skills, lacks conflict management skills, lacks strategy, lacks respect and credibility with other departments so expect little respect from other groups. On most days you can expect frustration dealing with all the challenges listed above along with high ambiguity with your work, many useless meetings facilitated by people that don't know what they're doing and working under a framework (SAFe Agile) that is a bad fit for this Design group. 
Most of the leads, managers, directors  don't have the skills to resolve these issues so don't bother trying to get help.

review_title: The troubling one-liner: "Not a call center" and how they did.
pros:
To start, the system I worked in was a specific part of Aetna's call center. This experience does not reflect the other call center model that Aetna employs. The Advocate model was fantastic, my work load was engaging but not overwhelming, collaboration is encouraged, and your calls are rated based on how you did not on how fast you go. The WFH temporary setup worked well. I didn't really engage in the benefits, since I already had insurance, but the PTO was fantastic for an hourly position.
A lot of call centers would like to pretend they don't struggle with the mindless pressure filled environment on the floor. Aetna is not perfect but I have to say I was constantly surprised to say that the team at the Advocate team really seems to care about the customer's experience and the employees. I think, overall, they did great, considering the nature of call work.
cons: Healthcare paper work is tedious and Aetna encourages it. I had to document every call twice, including outbounds. Another thing, the commitment to customers lead to a list of tasks that you have to balance, not great for those who struggle with anxiety.

pros:
Like every company this is no different. Aetna has good team managers and some that are like a bull in a China shop. Heartless and unpredictable.
Enjoyed working there for the first 6 years, I was getting spot bonus and good work assignments, until I got moved to workers comp. Everybody was a back stabber. This reflected on the team lead who was their role model.
cons:
Too many women, lol! There was not a good balance of men and women. The ratio was 70% women verses 30% men. No one listens to you when you submit a referral. It gets tossed in the circular file basket. Never even gets to the hiring manager.
Many nights I went home signed back on and worked until 10pm (unpaid) to get complex projects completed so we could be on time and on budget. Never got acknowledged.

pros:
Office in Soho. But that doesn't matter now because of covid. 

They sponsor h1b visas.
cons:
Analytics and Behavior Change (A&BC) in Soho is the fancy new data science org of Aetna. 

It's a giant sham for a company which should have perished by now but the healthcare industry in America keeps this dinosaur alive. 

When you enter the floor, you see rows and rows of Asians and South Asians toiling away on their computers (obviously all of them are visa slaves), not many companies sponsor under Trump administration so Aetna has that going for itself.

When you look around at the cabins , you see that most of them (if not all) are occupied by white men and maybe one 
white woman.

The dynamic is pretty apparent. The white people manage and the Asians and South Asians work. 

It's such a depressing environment that anyone who thinks otherwise is either a little deluded or in denial. 

Companies like Aetna are the epitome of what is wrong with America currently. It is a racist, sexist and depressing workplace and if you care about any of these issues, then you would stay away. 

If you want your h1b visa, then join. But know there is nothing to learn here, low chances of growth (especially if you are non white) and they pretend to be doing Data Science but most of the time they are just barely able to make their Hadoop clusters function half decently.

Do not fall for all the branding and ads on LinkedIn. Stay away if you value your sanity and well being.

review_title: No science in data science teams
pros: Above average salary in the industry
cons: Leaders claim to use analytics to promote member behavior changes for better health. However, they only care about cost savings for the company, sometimes even at the cost of members. Most of the analysis are based on unrealistic assumptions and are done with inrigorous methods. Managers have some ideas about actions member can take for which they believe will bring cost savings for the company. Then data scientist are expected to find evidence from data. If you cannot find it, you are screwed. If you find evidence, even with unsound analysis, you will be promoted. Managers really don't care about the correctness of your methods, as long as your result can help them meet their KPI. So you are encouraged to manipulate data in some ways that will meet the goals instead of respecting the truth. In such an organization, data scientists are really data artists. How can you expect to learn new skills besides ppt ? Leaders always boast their teams bring hundreds of millions savings for the company, and when they find the bubbles are about to burst, they will leave.

pros: You get a job. You'll get a laptop.
cons: If you are considering working here, I highly suggest you look elsewhere. Why? Several reasons..... 1. Upper Leadership has NO IDEA what they're doing. You will be given happy ideas but the leadership in Boston has no idea how anything works in the digital group in Denver. They will spin up meetings pretending to do so. 2. They have this idea of "DesignOps," but nobody in the group knows ANYTHING about actual design nor any actual background in UX. 3. The corporation is CVS and CVS does not care about you. In fact, your benefits through Aetna insurance is abysmal. Ask for details on deductibles and if you have any underlying health issues (you or your family) like terminal or chronic illnesses, they will only provide the lowest quality tech and medicine available. Better off w/ GoodRX and Obamacare. 4. During Covid, while CVS promoted this idea of massive testing and support for the US, they offered ZERO testing support for actual employees. They also said nothing about helping with vaccination. 5. The majority of employees there are just there to collect a paycheck. Do not expect inspiration or positive vibes. 6. SAFe. Look it up.

pros: The company as a whole was pretty ok; the other teams seemed happy and they enjoyed a healthy work life balance and seemed to get things done efficiently.
cons:
The fact that there was such disparity between the treatment / rules to be followed / and overall company atmosphere from team to team shows that there needs to be more cohesiveness within the company and upper management should keep a better eye on what lower management is up to.

My major issue were the lies that i was told upon hiring.  

- LIE: promised 8 hours is 8 hours and we can chose when our best work hours are / work from home options available 
TRUTH: You will be expected to come in at 9am every day.  They will mark you up for being 1 minute late and it will be a huge ego trip for your manager and cut down on productivity and employee moral.

- LIE: Promised to be working one on one with clients building relationships and experience.
TRUTH: Your boss takes all the client calls and commissions and honestly wants a less productive team so that he can make more money for himself.  i constantly tried to point out ways we could work smarter not harder and he was never willing to even consider changes or improvements to work flow.

IN GENERAL::


My experience was awful.  

We printed the proposal packages for potential or returning clients on broken printers that never worked properly and wasted hundreds of hours trying to fix hardware, definitely not my job or expertise.
 - The printers worked properly about as often as my boss who spent most of his work day chatting about new kids on the block and his marital problems with team members.  Nothing helps get insurance policies sold like your boss badmouthing his wife to young female employees.
-  In general my manager did not know appropriate demeanor toward women in the workplace. I was always alone in rooms with him and it always felt really uncomfortable.
- My manager actually poached me from another company to work for him and constantly made comments about “saving me” from my professional reality in front of other team members (i was much happier at my previous position).
- most of my team were awesome people but they spent the entire day chatting on the company chat app with me and everyone else. I don’t know how they got anything done.  I often felt overwhelmed by the amount of conversations coming at me from my coworkers that had nothing to do with our work.
- i was very micromanaged about some things (even non work related things like how i cooked my lunch in the kitchen) and never given proper training for more specialized tasks that require experience and company knowledge.

LAST.  And unlike most things i can’t blame my direct manager ENTIRELY though definitely in part,

The system we used was wildly inefficient and out of date.  Hundreds or more outdated answers to current questions were left in the system and finding the most accurate response took hours when it should have taken minutes. 

I created a system to organize these stock answers and when i shared it with the team my manager reassigned me to assembling packages instead of searching for answers and told higher management the idea to update and organize our system in a glossary was his (he has absolutely nothing to do with it except NOT fixing it before i got the chance)

In general i think the company was much better than the team i was working on, however, if they allow an employee in a management role to abuse his power and underperform so extensively i have to assume there are bigger issues within the company that i didn’t stick around to dissect.

Don’t work here; the money isn’t great and the job, even if it wasn’t a hot mess with management and outdated systems, would be wildly boring and depressing.  They reward mediocre work rather than innovation and are stuck in antiquity.  KEEP LOOKING OR YOULL GET STUCK HERE.

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Irving, TX
pros:
Pay is equal to most insurance companies. PTO is excellent adding up to essentially a paid month off (19+ days), and insurance is very available and cheap with a great HSA,
In general the managers are great. There was only one area where they were totally unsupportive, but it was a big one for me unfortunately.
cons: Health plan has a very high deductible and essentially nothing other than preventative actually covered unless you have catastrophic casualty that exceeds deductible. Everything else is paid out of your HSA, but Aetna does give you $1000 in the HSA per year. Company has rapid changes, like all insurance companies, and I had to learn and work in two EMRs at the same time. Biggest negative, that will probably cause me to leave, was that my particular position required I move at my expense and stay in a desert city (El Paso) even after we went to mostly online and my spouse started having serious mental health damage from separation from her support system. Management was great about everything else, but totally rejected any request to move and keep my job even though I work from home.

I reached out to this manager and was basically informed that she went out on vacation and handled my termination when she returned ( when she felt like it ) . This is leaving me with an option to pay $1,200 or receive a collection. I was also told I should have known I was over paid. I. have no way of logging into their system and pulling stubs for my last paycheck. Nor is that my responsibility. Payroll cut off was 7/4 I was in office until 7/8. I could have been informed before leaving on this. If a collection is placed on my credit that I worked my entire life for I will be going to court regarding this matter.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: The ability to work from home.
cons:
I was never really sure who I worked for, due to the merger. My pay stubs said CVS, my badge (although I was a Remote employee) said Aetna, and when I answered the phone, it was for one of their subsidiaries. When a coworker asked for clarity in training, "Management" couldn't even give a straight answer, because they are confused as well. That within itself, was a Red Flag. 

CVS, Aetna, or whatever else they call themselves, is just a big name that has been around for many years, and they lure in candidates with that, plus the incentives they provide. When you begin working for them, they will sell you the classic, "American Dream" by telling you how many ways you can move up in the company, and how everyone is one "Big Happy Family" and love to help employees, so feel free to ask TL's, Supervisors, and Managers for "Assistance" when you need it. Right....

After they put you on the phone to handle calls, you will have absolutely NO SUPPORT from "Leadership", and you may quickly burnout from the stress that comes with the job. Not to mention, they make the job a lot more difficult than it has to be, on so many levels. 

For instance, when you have a call where a Member or Provider is demanding to speak with a Supervisor, and you notify your helpful CVS/Aetna "Supervisor", you will be sent a link to an online job aid that tells you step by step, how to de-escalate the call. All while judging you on metrics. They also require employees to use several different systems, just to look up one simple thing, and they will train you to rely on "Help Desk" to get your questions answered. That way, they can pretend to be held up in "Meetings" all day. This is CVS/Aetna's version of, "Support".

Also, you may be unfortunate enough to be given a work schedule that has your first break beginning 1 hour and 5 minutes after you've just started your shift. Then, you have to sit and take calls for approx. 4 hours and 15 minutes straight, before you can go to lunch. Your last break will be scheduled 1 hour and 5 minutes before your shift ends. Business needs come first....

The high turnover is no surprise. 

Word of advice, after rightfully Resigning from the company, "Leadership" may wrongfully declare you as Terminated. This is what my "Manager" told me after I was courteous enough to email her and my "Supervisor", my Resignation Letter. 

For that reason alone, I'm even happier that I left them, and I would never want to work for CVS/Aetna again, even if they begged me and offered a higher salary than I was making, lol. Not worth my time.

I'm not trying to discourage anyone from applying, because things didn't work out for me. This was my experience with them, and it may be a better job fit for someone else. Especially if you are unemployed, and need something fast. If you honestly feel that you can handle all of the above, this is definitely the place for you. Good luck everyone!

pros:
Good Salary

cons:
Health Insurance, believe it or not, is bad. The insurance is expensive and carries a very high deductible. I found this to be ironic and sad. My co-workers, who had health insurance through their spouses had a better time of it.
Working from home is a double-edged sword. It saves the employee sometimes a very long commute, and gives them more opportunities to work in positions they might not otherwise have available in their locations. However, the temptation of having a work station in their home, there is a temptation to work 12-14 hours per day. It's easy to justify "donating" work time since you would normally waste those hours each day sitting in traffic. But that leads to thoughts of, "Hey! I've got insomnia; I'll just log on quickly and finish my presentation or paperwork." "I might as well stay logged in and finish my charting; I'm already saving 3 hours per day not sitting in traffic." The next thing you know, you haven't moved in hours, and your ankles are swollen. My last position, I logged in at 3am since I had insomnia, and my manager and supervisor were logged in and working from the previous day! It was insane! 
Also if you wanted the best rates for the lousy insurance, you had to do "metabolic testing" each year to get a modest "discount" on the insurance.

review_title: AVOID COMMERCIAL/NEW PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AT ALL COSTS
pros: The pay was great and bonuses were funded at 120% while I was there. Despite the many, many negatives, there are some wonderful and talented people who work there, including my supervisor and group members who are some of the most creative, dedicated colleagues I have ever had the privilege of working alongside. Also, although I worked remotely because of COVID, I heard the office had snacks. I'm really sorry I missed out on those.
cons:
If Dante had been born 700 years later and worked at Aetna, he would have made New Product Development the inner-most circle of hell in his ‘Inferno.’ Where to begin?

—HR—
HR does not exist in any meaningful or helpful way. Your only resources are a barely functional website and an 800 number you can call that funnels you into an endless maze designed to send you back to the website. If Kafka and Escher had a lovechild and that lovechild was an HR infrastructure, it would be easier to navigate than Aetna's HR-themed labyrinth.

Don't get me started about the actual HR department. In my experience, HR staff are only there to repeat the 800 number. At one point I had a serious medical emergency and reached out to HR with questions about taking a medical leave but received what amounted to a generic response from an HR representative reminding me of the HR number (which, in my experience, has SIGNIFICANT wait times to speak to poorly trained call centers)

—Tools for Success—
You do not get the tools and resources you need to be successful in your work, so don't even ask. The unwillingness Aetna has to properly equip its staff with the tools they need to be successful manifests itself in many ways but is most illustrated by the laptop I was given—an antique, battered, discount-level Dell with a Celeron processor and 2GB of RAM that was pre-loaded with so much corporate bloatware and spyware that it was functionally unusable. The laptop died about a week before I left, which honestly was great timing because someone needed to put it out of its misery before getting passed along to the next poor sucker.

—Onboarding—
You do not get this either, and DEFINITELY don't ask about it.* When I logged in on my first day, I had 70 unread emails, some of which contained helpful information about the company and my job. Believe it or not, Aetna/CVS, a Fortune FIVE company, does not have any kind of formal onboarding. There are no centralized resources, no orientation sessions, no 400-page dictionary explaining the absurd amount of acronyms that are un-Googlable but required to be fluent in from Day 1 so that you don’t sound like a complete dope, NOTHING. During my time in Ner Product Development, several talented people left the organization after 1-3 year stints without ever having gained a basic understanding of how the company works or how they were supposed to be successful in their roles.

*Seriously, don't ask about onboarding. NPD leadership does not care about the onboarding experience and actively discouraged any informal efforts to develop materials to help new employees. That should tell you everything you need to know.

—Training—
Do you work in product but feel like you need a working understanding of how to print member communications? Well, you’re in luck because Aetna has a quarterly required training for you! Do you work remotely, but still want to know how to prevent violence in the workplace? Well, you’re in luck because Aetna has a quarterly required training for you! Are you desperate to understand how physical records should be managed, even though your work is completely digital, and your antique laptop would poop its own pants at the thought of having to connect to a printer? Well, you’re in luck because Aetna has a quarterly required training for you! Are you a stressed-out Product Director who would give anything to understand how the company works so that he can be better and more productive at his job? Well, you’re in luck because—j/k, they’ll never help you with that, so quit thinking about it!

—Product Development Process—
LOL. Product Development takes place within what I’d call a “blinded waterfall development” framework where you work in nearly complete isolation from the decision-makers who decide whether your product will move on to the next stage of development. Funding for new products is minimal or non-existent, which forces stakeholders to be incredibly territorial and hesitant to sign off on new products. There are also required technical feedback sessions where dozens and dozens of stakeholders provide feedback on new product concepts. These meetings, which are required to move your product forward, usually end with one or two of the 50+ attendees derailing the conversation so that another 50+ person meeting needs to be scheduled. I’m starting to think this is why our healthcare system is broken…

Did I mention funding? In my year at Aetna, I was never able to understand where funding came from and who needed to approve it. It was much easier to understand who can block or delay funding—nearly anyone. In fact, I’m pretty sure as a former Aetna employee I could still go back and derail a new product, that’s the Aetna difference! Products were constantly getting canceled or pushed back, even after significant resources had been invested in their development. Does the idea of a $100,000 PowerPoint deck getting shot down 5 minutes into a stage-gate meeting by a stakehoplder you’ve never met and didn't even know you needed to get buy-in from excite you? Then congratulations, you’re perfect for Aetna—enjoy your employee discount at CVS!

But at least we moved quickly! NOT! As a member of the “Disruptive Innovation Team,” I was tasked with thinking about and developing solutions for new issues in healthcare. That part was really fun, and I’m proud of the work I led. Unfortunately, those good ideas ran into a buzzsaw when we tried to turn them into products. I guess we just have to cross our fingers and hope that our COVID-19 ideas will be ready in time for the next global pandemic? That's not to mention all of the programs and products that gain momentum before getting mysteriously sidelined at the last minute because of "changing organizational priorities."

—Staffing—
The organization is incredibly top-heavy and everyone is overpaid. I reported up to a Senior Director (who was wonderful!), who then reported up through several levels of VPs (between 3 and 5, depending on that month's re-orgs!). I was a director but had no direct reports. There were no junior staff or analysts, and we don’t staff for individual parts of the development process, so the same Product Director would lead early ideation, business case development, pilot development, implementation, and sales. This actually isn’t unreasonable for a Director-level staff member, except for the fact that we were individual contributors, so we were doing every bit of work for all of these stages ourselves. Internal customer service is abysmal—it’s like a matrix organizational structure except there is no matrix or structure, just chaos. Leadership's way to address this, and the unbelievably inefficient product development process, was to complain about understaffing. Sure.

—Management—
When Socrates listed Ignorance among the passions, he might as well have been talking about NPD “leadership.” Despite a rapidly changing healthcare landscape, management seemed to proactively avoid thinking or learning about consumerism in healthcare, value-based care, digital health, interoperability, or anything else that might help them better navigate and address the disruption in our industry. Product leadership comes largely from consulting and sales, so rather than leveraging their client-facing experience while adapting their approach to manage a product organization, they just repeat the same complaints they heard from plan sponsors 10 years ago at Aon while refusing to learn anything about actual product development. With the incredible amount of experience WITHIN their organization, the amount of ignorance at the VP level was embarrassing.

—Insurance—
Perhaps the most frustrating part of working for Aetna is also having Aetna for an insurance provider. Aetna employees choose between three terrible, high deductible plans that left me, for the first time in my life, feeling like I didn’t even have insurance. I guess I could have lucked out and broken my leg on the first day of the plan year, but otherwise, I was basically stuck paying out of pocket for my care. Most employees who had working spouses opted out, but those of us who weren’t so lucky had to live with the fact that, not only didn’t Aetna seem to care about its members, it also didn’t seem to care about its employees. I spent part of my time looking at mental health and, in conversations with colleagues across the company, learned that many of my colleagues were paying out of pocket for their mental health care rather than deal with Aetna’s absolutely abysmal behavioral health offerings. Our EAP product wasn’t much better, although, unlike therapy and psychiatry, it was super easy to access their homework help hotline so at least they’ve got that going for them (which is nice)!

—Conclusion—
It was a mistake to work at Aetna. If you take pride in your work, this is not the place to work. If you want to help members achieve better health outcomes, this is not the place to work. If you have a blackened heart, hate people, and only care about money, this is probably the perfect place for you (but please seek help, although good luck getting help if you have Aetna because their behavioral health network is a tiny, insufficient dumpster fire).
